<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_pool_destroy:
```c
void
MHD_pool_destroy (struct MemoryPool *pool)
{
  if (NULL == pool)
    return;

  mhd_assert (pool->end >= pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->size >= pool->end - pool->pos);
  mhd_assert (pool->pos == ROUND_TO_ALIGN (pool->pos));
  _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY (pool->memory, pool->size);
  if (! pool->is_mmap)
    free (pool->memory);
  else
#if defined(MAP_ANONYMOUS) && ! defined(_WIN32)
    munmap (pool->memory,
            pool->size);
#elif defined(_WIN32)
    VirtualFree (pool->memory,
                 0,
                 MEM_RELEASE);
#else
    abort ();
#endif
  free (pool);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only selection/iteration controlling expressions are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. The fragments above include all instances in this function that either are direct controlling expressions (the two if statements) or are macros (mhd_assert) that commonly expand to conditional checks and therefore should be inspected for invariant conditions after macro expansion. The preprocessor conditional block around the platform-specific deallocation is included because it determines which runtime branch is compiled in; its effect on invariance should be checked in the build configurations. Other lines in the function (calls such as _MHD_UNPOISON_MEMORY, free(pool), the individual memory-deallocation calls when treated as statements, local expressions that are not controlling expressions, and non-conditional macro uses) do not introduce controlling expressions and thus do not need investigation under Rule 14.3.
